channel.title: How does an interpreter work? Implementing a language?
channel.description:
Sorry if the title was a little off, didn't know what to title this.
Out of general interest; I was wondering how hardware works and what's behind creating a computer, all the software/hardware, interpretation, compiling etc.
I wanted to know how the computer knows what machine language is, I mean like if you take a computers boot loader as an example, it's written in assembly but how does the computer know what assembly is? Sure an interpreter does that but then how does the interpreter know what to do or tell the computer what it is?
I know its compiled into byte-code but the computer somehow knows what to do with the instructions its given.
How is everything implemented? http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Programming_language_implementation - needing more expansion to whats on here since it's not as detailed as I'd like.
Sorry if I sound stupid lol :p
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Edit: Graham give me a nice informative insight on how CPU's execute machine code. Was a cool read on how old CPU works https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classic_RISC_pipeline
I'm guessing it's all down to the ALU http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arithmetic_logic_unit
Just lots of complicated stuff lol

item.title: How does an interpreter work? Implementing a language?
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:4, topic:535505”][quote author=sspoke link=topic=654314.msg4382950#msg4382950 date=1384203803]
byte-code is ran by java.exe which re-translates byte-code back to assembly.

assembly is hard-coded into the CPU that’s the language of the CPU. Although the CPU uses the assembly as just a bunch of binary data people made it easier to read with words like PUSH, ADD, POP, JMP, CALL.

assembly binary data is like a stream class in runescape private servers one bad byte and the bytes won’t be translated properly after that.
[/quote]

This is like half true. The java runs a virtual machine which is an application that interprets bytecode, the virtual machine doesn’t convert bytecode into assembly.[/quote]

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Just-in-time_compilation

Read full topic
item.source: How does an interpreter work? Implementing a language?

item.title: How does an interpreter work? Implementing a language?
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

Computer Science: An Overview by Brookshear is also a good read if you’re interested in some more general topics in CS as well. He also covers the questions you ask in the book.

Read full topic

item.title: How does an interpreter work? Implementing a language?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“sspoke, post:2, topic:535505”]byte-code is ran by java.exe which re-translates byte-code back to assembly.

assembly is hard-coded into the CPU that’s the language of the CPU. Although the CPU uses the assembly as just a bunch of binary data people made it easier to read with words like PUSH, ADD, POP, JMP, CALL.

assembly binary data is like a stream class in runescape private servers one bad byte and the bytes won’t be translated properly after that.[/quote]

This is like half true. The java runs a virtual machine which is an application that interprets bytecode, the virtual machine doesn’t convert bytecode into assembly.

item.title: How does an interpreter work? Implementing a language?
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

ftp://gnu.mirrors.pair.com/savannah/pgubook/ProgrammingGroundUp-1-0-lettersize.pdf

i’d recommend devouring the whole book, but the first 4 or so chapters should answer a lot of your questions.

then

maybe dragon book for your questions on language implementation? it covers pretty much everything behind languages and compilers. idk how comfortable you’d be with it though, it’s certainly not as “easy” as PFTGU.

if there’s anything more specific that you want to ask, don’t be afraid to.

Read full topic
item.source: How does an interpreter work? Implementing a language?

item.description:
@sspoke wrote:

byte-code is ran by java.exe which re-translates byte-code back to assembly.

assembly is hard-coded into the CPU that’s the language of the CPU. Although the CPU uses the assembly as just a bunch of binary data people made it easier to read with words like PUSH, ADD, POP, JMP, CALL.

assembly binary data is like a stream class in runescape private servers one bad byte and the bytes won’t be translated properly after that.
